_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Hardin County Water District No. 1's (HCWD#1) Pirtle Springs Water Treament Plant (PWP) has been active in reducing risks associated with using chlorine gas (cl2) as a disinfectant in our water treatment process. Over the past years, HCWD#1 has spent $20,000 for a building to store and confine (quantity) 4 - ton cylinders of chlorine.  To minimize escaping cl2 gas, a cl2 gas detector was installed to set off alarms if a cl2 leak is detected over 3 ppm ( parts per million).  If this situation ever occurs, HCWD#1 has a planned course of action to notify surrounding residences, police, medical personnel, fire department, and local government agencies.                                                                                                                                                    
PWP's plan for accidental prevention is following Standard Operating Procedures(SOPs) that are reviewed and updated annually and state the guidelines for handling cl2, daily inspections by the operators of the equipment used in the processes, and routine maintenance on the equipment used in the processes.  Emergency responce procedures at our facility are as follows.
1. Notify the facility emergency response coordinator or the alternate(s) of the potential problem.

2. Put on the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) - i.e. SCBA, rubber gloves, etc.)

3. Verify leak visually with ammonia.  The detector should also be reset as changes in the temperature may cause the alarm to inadvertently activate.                                                                     

4. Should a substantial leak be confirmed, PWP personnel will evacuate with the plant emergency cell phone (which is kept by the operators control computer) and a copy of the Tab-Q-7 (which is kept in both PWP vehicles).

5. Prior to exiting the PWP grounds, PWP personnel should observe and note wind direction.  Wind direction will dictate personnel evacuation route as well as emergency res

ponse personnel's approaching route to the plant.

6. At first opportunity, once clear from the site, evacuating personnel should contact MS. ANITA WOOD via phone (865-982-4242) and advise her that there is a chlorine leak and that she and her family should evacuate.  She is the most immediate neighbor to the plant.

7. Once evacuated from the plant and as soon as the WOOD family has been notified, plant personnel are to begin notifying the people and/or agencies identified on pages q-7-11-2, q-7-11-3, and q-7-11-6 from the Tab-Q-7 plan for PWP.

8. When contacting emergency services, personnel on site should provide the following information:

A. Identify who you are.
B. Identify the plant location.
C. Identify your location.
D. Advise as to the nature of the emergency (chlorine leak).
E. Advise as to the wind direction and best direction to approach the plant.
F. Remind those you contact that the staging area is Franklin Crossroads Baptist Church, 4695 Hardinsburg Rd. Cecilia, KY 42724.
G. Advise those contacted that the company radio frequency is 173.39625.
H. Give them the number of the PWP cell phone (270)268-0249.
I. Remind the contact, once again where you are and that your primary responsibility at this point is to close Shipley Road and make emergency contacts.

9. Remember that the primary objective at this point is to:

A. To keep the general population out of harms way (keep Shipley Road closed).
B. Notify emergency response personnel of the situation.
C. Keep the cell phone with you.
D. Keep yourself out of harms way.

HCWD#1 PWP is located in Cecilia, Kentucky.  Raw water for PWP is pumped in from Pirtle Springs and from Gray Lane (Head of Rough).  The raw (untreated) water then undergoes coagulation, flocculation, and sedimentation by means of chemicals.  These chemicals take out dirt and impurities found in raw water.  During this process cl2(chlorine) is added, disinfecting the water at the top of the filters.  The water the

n travels to the filters, where the 99.99% of the remaining impurities in the water are removed.  The water then travels through a pipe where fluoride is added and a second dose of chlorine is added.  After passing through the clearwell at PWP, the water is then pumped out into the distribution system where it supplies water to approximately 10,000 service connections located in the county and in the City of Radcliff.  HCWD #1 also supplies water to the City of Vine Grove and Meade County Water District.

NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES ON SHIFTS:  Day shift 1-4 people, Hrs. 7:45 am to 4:15 pm 
                                2nd shift 1 person, Hrs. 3:45 pm to 12:15 am 
                                3rd shift 1 person, Hrs. 11:45 pm to 8:15 am 
   
The PWP can provide up to 3.1 millon gallons of drinking water per day. We can store up to 8,000 lbs.(four- two ton cylinders) of chlorine-but only one is used at a time in the disinfection process.
